'''Angamaitë''' was one of the great-grandsons of [[Castamir]] the Usurper.<ref name=Telemnar>{{App|Gondor}}, entry for king Telemnar</ref>

== History ==
He and [[Sangahyando]], another great-grandson of Castamir, were leaders of the [[Corsairs of Umbar]].<ref name=ElendilC>{{PM|Elendil}}, manuscript C, The Heirs of Elendil, The Southern Line of Gondor: the Anarioni, 25. Minardil, p. 199</ref> The name Angamaitë was possibly not his birth name, but a personal warrior name (or nickname). There was no need to assert his royal descent with this name, because his royal descent was clear.<ref name=L347>{{L|347}}</ref>

Angamaitë and Sangayando learned through spies that [[Minardil]], the [[King of Gondor]], was in the [[Gondor]]ian port of [[Pelargir]] and that he suspected no peril since his father had crushed Harad and Umbar.<ref name=ElendilC/> In {{TA|1634}}<ref name=TA1634>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1634</ref><ref name=T4>{{PM|Third}}, manuscript T4, entry for the year 1634</ref> the Corsairs of Umbar, led by Angamaitë and Sangayando, made a raid up the river [[Anduin]], killed king Minardil in Pelargir,<ref name=Telemnar/> ravaged Pelargir<ref name=TA1634/><ref name=T4/> and the coasts and escaped with great booty.<ref name=ElendilC/>

== Etymology ==
{{Seealso|Angamaitë (epessë)}}
''Angamaitë'' is a [[Quenya]] name meaning "Iron-handed",<ref name=L347/> from ''[[anga]]'' ("iron") and ''[[maitë]]'' ("handed").<ref name=PE17>{{PE|17}}, p. 116 entry Q ''angamaite'' and p. 162 entry '''MAG'''</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In the manuscripts for what would later become appendix A and appendix B and in appendix A in the first edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' his name was ''Angomaitë''.<ref name=ElendilC/><ref name=T4/> His name was changed to ''Angamaitë'' in the second edition of The Lord of the Rings.<ref name=PE17/><ref>{{PM|Elendil}}, Commentary relating to the entry for king Minardil in manuscript B, p. 215</ref>
